Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Story: I gripped the shopping cart a little tighter as my son darted down the cereal aisle, his laughter echoing off the shelves. I knew I should call him back, remind him about respecting public spaces and behaving properly—he needed to learn discipline, and this was one of those moments where my words and actions mattered. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, and I glanced at the screen: an urgent message from my project manager. The new safety standard documentation was due by the end of the day, and I still hadn’t finished compiling the evidence for compliance. My mind raced with the technical details I needed to double-check, the forms I had to fill out, and the pressure of knowing that a single oversight could mean a failed audit. I felt torn, standing in the middle of the supermarket, my son’s voice growing fainter as he disappeared around the corner, while my work responsibilities pressed in from the other side. I could feel the weight of both roles—parent and engineer—pulling me in opposite directions, each demanding my immediate attention, each unwilling to wait.
